awd_titl_txt: CNH-L: Coupled Social and Ecological Consequences of Conservation Easements
awd_abstract_narration:
A private land conservation tool, conservation easements, have become widely used in the United States over the past thirty years, and their popularity may correspond to tax laws creating incentives for private land conservation in the public interest. This research project will examine how shifting dynamics between conservation easement holders, easement donors/sellers, regional land use pressures, and connections to conserved lands are affecting the spatial pattern, public benefit and ecological integrity of conservation easements in different regions of the United States. These dynamics will be examined at the fine scale; national and regional policy structures will be linked at the land parcel-level. How public input during the conservation easement process affects the spatial use of easements, as well as the neighborhood effects of easements on adjacent and county-level land costs, will be analyzed. Results from this research will be useful to land use planners, both public and private, who will benefit from a better understanding of the conveyance process and the environmental outcomes. Students will be trained in database creation and assessment, strengthening the nation's scientific workforce. 

Employing multivariate, spatial overlay, and time-series analyses, the relationship between political and legal factors and conservation easement propagation will be examined. Regional spatial datasets will be combined with the results from county-level easement donor surveys and both fine and coarse filter ecological integrity approaches to assess whether conservation easements whose purpose is to maintain biological integrity have a higher likelihood of contributing to reserve networks in their spatial arrangement than do other conservation easements. Whether this is more likely to occur in areas with public oversight in the easement placement process will be determined. How the environmental outcomes affect the easement decision process will be addressed. Theory will be advanced by examining the geographic effect of the easement tool, and how social factors may influence its use, in a single spatial and quantitative framework. Broader impacts will include better understanding of the complete conservation easement process for planners and land owners and the training of undergraduate and graduate students.

por.por_cntn:
We set out and continue to evaluate the spatial, social, and ecological manifestation of conservation easements (CEs) in growing exurban, eco-regionally representative Census regions of the country. To do so, we assembled fine-scale datasets in twelve counties in six states (Sonoma and Sacramento, CA; Boulder and Mesa, CO; Washington and Douglas, MN; York and Lebanon, PA; Albemarle and Loudoun, VA; and Charleston and Greenville, SC), allowing comparison both within and between these states and regions. We also conducted interviews with 20 of the 49 possible land trusts (LTs) holding the CEs in these counties and administered a survey to the entire population of CE holders in each county for CEs placed during our study periods (1997 - 2008/2009). Despite challenges with data management and recording at the county level, we are currently generating results and are sharing the following ones to date (our analysis is on-going and will continue for additional years despite the end of the grant):

  • The CEs are significantly spatially clustering in similar patterns over time, despite the heterogeneity of the counties.
  • The county tax-assessed land uses associated with the CE properties show that CEs are manifesting on agricultural land and residential land over time, with larger parcel size in the agricultural land but greater volume in residential parcels. The reasons for the CEs are not necessarily correspondent with the tax-assessed land use.
  • As compared to similarly situated parcels without CEs in five study counties, CEs were significantly more natural in three counties and were less natural in one county while they were the same in yet another county. Across all five counties, publicly conserved lands were significantly lower in the amount of human impact and modification than both CE lands and other similarly situated properties without CEs. 
  • While we haven't yet determined causality, the level of human modification on CE lands may be attributed to the heterogeneity in the LT missions and the nature of their CE acquisition. The majority of these LTs are oriented toward biological purposes but there are some that are focused solely on agricultural or wetland mitigation banking.
  • Additionally, there is a spectrum of reasons for the 2,823 coded CEs themselves. We found that, regardless of county, each one had increasing numbers of reasons per CE over time, suggesting that complexity and/or specificity increased accordingly. This confirms the evolution in CE acceptance process as the LTs became accredited by the Land Trust Alliance.
  • Our datasets also showed a significant increase in biological reasons originally demonstrated in Kiesecker et al. (2007)'s and Rissman et al. (2007)'s dataset. Our top reason counts support those in Wallace et al. (2008), showing that open space and scenic value are the highest in absolute count across the CEs, regardless of region. And we do see a significantly increasing use of direct IRS code language over time, which may indicate a concern with compliance and a move toward uniformity (McLaughlin & Pidot, 2013). However, our results deviate from previous findings in the following ways: our third highest overall CE reason was agricultural viability, which was not present in the previous findings. In these growing exurban areas, the CEs are placed to preserve either the biological values of the land (with endangered species being the code with the most significantly increasing use over time, followed closely by the IRS code for maintenance of a relatively natural habitat), or to maintain the open space and scenic value of the properties. But in the Pennsylvania counties, the agricultural viability was quite prevalent, which relates to the LT missions (and state programs) for agricultural conservation.
  • Albeit extremely preliminary and skewed toward the East Coast, the survey results from landowners in our study counties suggested that CE placement motivations confirm but are more nuanced than those previously identified in the literature, including being a biotic citizen, monetary incentives (property taxes, fiscal payment, leaving land in agricultural use), eco-contagion effect (land's ecological resources, neighbors and friends/family, etc. granting a CE), tax influence, and protectionism (plants and animals on the land, don't trust subsequent landowners, etc.). And regardless of CE reasons, in almost all of the counties, respondents highly valued the following motivations for CE placement: feeling responsible for the future health of the land and cherishing what the land has given.
  • Our experience gathering CE records from county register of deeds offices revealed shortcomings in CE document recording. This supports existing arguments in the literature for standardizing CE recording procedures (i.e., distinct indexes for CEs, standardized document titles for CEs, and compulsory state registries for CE records).

The county tax-assessed land uses associated with the CE properties show that CEs are manifesting on agricultural land and residential land over time, with larger parcel size in the agricultural land but greater volume in residential parcels. The reasons for the CEs are not necessarily correspondent with the tax-assessed land use.

Across all five counties, publicly conserved lands were significantly lower in the amount of human impact and modification than both CE lands and other similarly situated properties without CEs. 
While we haven't yet determined causality, the level of human modification on CE lands may be attributed to the heterogeneity in the LT missions and the nature of their CE acquisition. The majority of these LTs are oriented toward biological purposes but there are some that are focused solely on agricultural or wetland mitigation banking.
Additionally, there is a spectrum of reasons for the 2,823 coded CEs themselves. We found that, regardless of county, each one had increasing numbers of reasons per CE over time, suggesting that complexity and/or specificity increased accordingly. This confirms the evolution in CE acceptance process as the LTs became accredited by the Land Trust Alliance.
Our datasets also showed a significant increase in biological reasons originally demonstrated in Kiesecker et al. (2007)'s and Rissman et al. (2007)'s dataset. Our top reason counts support those in Wallace et al. (2008), showing that open space and scenic value are the highest in absolute count across the CEs, regardless of region. And we do see a significantly increasing use of direct IRS code language over time, which may indicate a concern with compliance and a move toward uniformity (McLaughlin & Pidot, 2013). However, our results deviate from previous findings in the following ways: our third highest overall CE reason was agricultural viability, which was not present in the previous findings. But in the Pennsylvania counties, the agricultural viability was quite prevalent, which relates to the LT missions (and state programs) for agricultural conservation.
Albeit extremely preliminary and skewed toward the East Coast, the survey results from landowners in our study counties suggested that CE placement motivations confirm but are more nuanced than those previously identified in the literature, including being a biotic citizen, monetary incentives (property taxes, fiscal payment, leaving land in agricultural use), eco-contagion effect (land's ecological resources, neighbors and friends/family, etc. granting a CE), tax influence, and protectionism (plants and animals on the land, don't trust subsequent landowners, etc.). And regardless of CE reasons, in almost all of the counties, respondents highly valued the following motivations for CE placement: feeling responsible for the future health of the land and cherishing what the land has given.
Our experience gathering CE records from county register of deeds offices revealed shortcomings in CE document recording. This supports existing arguments in the literature for standardizing CE recording procedures (i.e., distinct indexes for CEs, standardized document titles for CEs, and compulsory state registries for CE records).
